Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the impact of the California law by stating that President Trump was "kicked off" the ballot, when in fact the law only requires candidates to release their tax returns to run in the state's primary.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the California law is unconstitutional and disenfranchises millions of voters without providing enough evidence to support this assumption.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to back up its assertion that the law is unconstitutional and disenfranchises voters. It only mentions that lawsuits have been filed and some legal analysts have questioned it.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the California law does not prevent Trump or any other candidate from appearing on the ballot, as it only applies to the primary election and not the general election.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for why the California law was passed, such as the aim of increasing transparency and accountability for presidential candidates.
